body_content.explanation: a process in which the light coming from far away objects in space is seen to move from the blue end of the spectrum (= the range of colours into which a beam of light can be separated) to the red end as it moves farther away, because the wavelengths (= the distances between the waves of energy) become longer:
examples: The redshift of an object directly indicates the relative size of the universe when light was emitted.
The Berkeley astronomers measured the supernovae by analysing their red shift.
